p:
NOX2 seems to be involved in the production of ROS during IV infection [ 13, 75]. In a mouse model, Nox2-derived superoxide is critical for IV-induced pulmonary damage. Nox2
–/– knockout (KO) mice exhibited a milder airway inflammation and less apoptosis in the alveolar epithelium after IV infection than did wild-type mice [ 75]. The IV-mediated production of ROS and RNS was also decreased in Nox2
–/– KO mice [ 75]. In another study, the titer of active competent viruses and their associated inflammatory activities were decreased in these KO mice [ 72]. These findings suggest that NOX2 is a candidate for anti-ROS treatment to manage IV infection [ 75].
